original_title: Sri Lanka plans to extend leases of plantations: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is planning to extend the leases of privatized Regional Plantations Companies (RPC) State Minister for Plantations Lohan Ratwatte said.
“I would like to tell that we are going to extend the leases of the RPCs,” Minister Ratwatte told reporters.

“What Sri Lanka needs is national policies. We need to get that in place. Whatevre govermnt that comes in does whatever they want. If we want to go forward, we have to have national policies. So we are working on that.”
Sri Lanka’s RPCs were sold to the private sector with a 50 year lease on land in the 1990s.
The plantations grow tea, rubber and oil palm. Under private management they have also diversified into other crops.
It is no clear on what basis the leases will be extended or whether all leases will be extended.

Plantations have to make long term investments in tea and other trees, going up to 30 years, Roshan Rajadurai, spokesman for Sri Lanka’s Planters Association made up of managers of the RPCs said. (Colombo/June21/2023)
